To Kill a Mockingbird.passage: To Kill a Mockingbird is a 1962 novel by Harper Lee. The story takes place in the fictional small town of Maycomb, Alabama, during the Great Depression and centers on the experiences of Scout Finch and her brother Jem as they grow up in the pre-Civil Rights South during the 1930s. The novel is narrated by Scout, age nine, and Jem, age seven, and follows their adventures and those of their friends, relatives, and neighbors. The novel has been acclaimed by critics and has enjoyed wide popularity since its publication. It won the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction in 1961, and Lee won the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction in 1961 and the U.S. National Book Award for Fiction in 1964. The novel has been widely taught in middle and high schools across the United States, and continues to be widely popular among teenagers and adults. It was adapted as an Academy Award-winning film in 1962 and a highly acclaimed 1962 television series, as well as a play and a musical. In 2015, a second film adaptation of the novel premiered, with an all-star cast.

The Great Gatsby.passage: The Great Gatsby is a 1925 novel by American author F. Scott Fitzgerald, and is his last major work of fiction. It is set in the summer of 1922 on Long Island, New York, during the "Roaring Twenties". The book follows the lives of Jay Gatsby and his lover Daisy Buchanan, and of Nick Carraway, a Midwesterner who becomes a neighbor and friend of Gatsby. The novel portrays the American Dream in the Jazz Age as a deceitful myth, and explores the emptiness of the American dream and the American Dreamer.

The Catcher in the Rye.passage: "In The Catcher in the Rye", the main character, Holden Caulfield, is a 17-year-old boy who is forced to stay at home after being kicked out of Pencey Prep, a private school he had attended. He spends his days wandering around New York City and dealing with various people he encounters, including the wealthy, spoiled Phoebe and her brother, Phineas. Holden is an unreliable narrator, and the reader is not privy to his innermost thoughts and feelings, but is given glimpses into the thoughts and feelings of others. Holden is a confused and cynical youth, but is also lonely and searching for a place to belong. He is constantly being ridiculed by the adults he encounters, including his parents, and is constantly trying, but failing, to escape from the world around him. The story follows Holden from his first day of summer vacation to his return to school in late September. The novel is narrated in the present tense as an adult looking back on the events of Holden's adolescence, but it is written in a style that is reminiscent of a diary. The novel's title comes from the nickname of a catcher on a baseball team, who is responsible for calling pitches to the batter and for throwing out base runners.

Harry Potter.passage: Harry Potter is a series of fantasy novels written by British author J. K. Rowling, and adapted into a film series by Warner Bros.. The books and films chronicle the life of Harry Potter, a young wizard, and his friends Hermione Granger and Ron Weasley, both of whom are also wizards, as they learn to cope with a dark wizard, Lord Voldemort, who is seeking to become immortal, and who has a personal vendetta against Harry's parents. The main story arc of the seven books and eight films follows Harry as he grows from an orphaned child into a responsible young adult, learns to master the powers that he has inherited from his parents, and defeats Voldemort. The books and films explore themes of death, love, loyalty, friendship, and the triumph of good over evil. The books were originally published in the United Kingdom from 1990 to 2007, and were popular worldwide. The books have gained a wide following, with more than 400 million copies sold, making them the best-selling books of all time.

Animal Farm.passage: Animal Farm is a novella by George Orwell, first published in 1945. It satirizes the Russian Revolution of 1917 and the Stalinist regime that came to power later that year. The book describes a group of farm animals who rebel against the human farmer, Jones, and his work-consisting-of-feeding-the-pigs attitude, and establish an egalitarian society in which the pigs are oppressed. The animals start by overthrowing Jones and his work-consisting-of-feeding-the-pigs attitude, and establish an egalitarian society in which all the animals are equal and free. The pigs, who are the smartest animals, take over this society and start to oppress the other animals in order to maintain their status. The animals, led by the barn-owl, rebel against the pigs and their new society, and return to the ideals of Jones. The animals re-establish Jones' work-consisting-of-feeding-the-pigs attitude, but with the addition of some work-consisting-of-rearing-the-pigs attitude. The animals establish a system of "Animal Farm", in which they all share equally and work together. However, the pigs, being intelligent and greedy, start to take over the farm, and become more prosperous.

qae_pairs.question: Who is the author of Animal Farm?
qae_pairs.explanation: George Orwell

Brave New World.passage: Brave New World is a 1932 novel by English author Aldous Huxley. Set in the year 2540, it describes a utopian society in which the polar ice caps have melted, and the world is in a state of perpetual ecological crisis. The story is told from the point of view of the Savage, a character who has spent his childhood in the wilderness, but is educated and cultured enough to converse with the other main characters. The novel satirizes the ideas of progress and rationalism popularized by Victorian England. Huxley was among the most prominent intellectuals of the 1920s and 30s, but Brave New World was rejected by his literary contemporaries. It was published serially in a magazine, and when it was finally published in book form in 1932, it received mixed reviews. The book's reputation grew over time, and by the 1960s, it had become widely accepted as one of the great 20th-century works of literature. It has been adapted for film, television, and theater, and is widely considered a classic of the genre of utopian and dystopian fiction. The novel's themes of conformity, hedonism, and passivity have been the subject of extensive critical analysis. Huxley himself saw it as a cautionary tale, warning against the dehumanizing effects of modern technology.

the U.S. National Book Award for Fiction.term: the U.S. National Book Award for Fiction
the U.S. National Book Award for Fiction.passage: The award was first presented in 1936. The Book of the Month Club was the original sponsor. The award was originally called the "National Book Award for Fiction" but was renamed in 1970 to avoid confusion with the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction. The award is given by the National Book Foundation (NBF), a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization that promotes the appreciation of the written word and the reading experience through educational and other activities. J.R.R. Tolkien.passage:
J. R. R. Tolkien ( /ˈtrɒlkiːn/;[a],[n] ; 22 May 1892 – 2 January 1973) was an English writer and poet best known as the author of the high fantasy novels The Hobbit (1937), The Lord of the Rings (1954–1955) and The Silmarillion (published posthumously in 1977), and the creator of a fictional universe known as Middle-earth. [b]
Tolkien was born and brought up in Bloemfontein, South Africa, where his father worked for the Orange Free State government. He returned to England in 1916 at the age of twenty-four, during World War I. There he joined the Inklings literary discussion group, which included C. S. Lewis and other eminent writers of the time. The group met at the University of Oxford's pub "The Eagle and Child". Tolkien's academic career was marked by periods of teaching at Oxford and Cambridge, as well as a year in Iceland as a university professor. He published The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings while working in Birmingham during World War II, and the latter was an international best-seller. He retired to Bournemouth in the 1960s and became a professor of Anglo-Saxon, a subject of which he was an acknowledged expert.

qae_pairs.explanation: J.R.R. Tolkien was born and brought up in Bloemfontein, South Africa, where his father worked for the Orange Free State government. He returned to England in 1916 at the age of twenty-four, during World War I. There he joined the Inklings literary discussion group, which included C. S. Lewis and other eminent writers of the time. Warner Bros.passage: Warner Bros. Records (also known as Warner Bros. or WBR) is an American major record label owned by Warner Music Group (WMG). The label was founded as the American branch of the British company The Gramophone Company Ltd., and was acquired by American business magnate Jack L. Warner in 1929. Warner's son-in-law, Lenny Waronker, is the current Chairman and CEO of Warner Bros. Records. Warner Bros. Records is one of the \"Big Three\" American record companies, alongside Sony Music Entertainment and Universal Music Group. The label has also released records for other artists, such as The Rolling Stones, The Doors, Metallica, The Black Keys, and Lady Gaga. The Warner Bros. Records Group also operates the independent record label Rhino Records and the music publisher Warner/Chappell Music. The company's headquarters is at the Warner Bros. Building in Burbank. The label has a long history of innovation, including its first stereo recordings in 1951, the LP in 1948, the first 33 ⅓ rpm long-playing records in 1948, and the first 12-inch vinyl records in 1949. The company's most famous artists are the Warner Bros. cartoons (which include Looney Tunes and Merrie Melodies) and the Warner Bros. film soundtracks (such as The Godfather, Joker, and The Hangover).
